Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2010 11:14PM sdisilvestri wrote: Hi Texas, Just wanted to say that I am also the mother of young children (I have seven, actually, age 1 through 12).  I was diagnosed Stage IV from the get go at age 38.  I, too, was told I had mastitis  when my four month old refused to nurse on one side and had to insist, over three different visits to the doctor, to get them to take me seriously that something was actually wrong. Like so many of the others have already told you, do not lose hope!  You will definitely find your new normal and your kids will be a big part of keeping you grounded.  Life goes on, different, but not always bad.  In fact, there are many blessings that this all has brought me.  I have liver and bone mets, and all are currently very well controlled.  My first prognosis was 18 months "tops" and now I am hearing much better (decades, perhaps).  Treatment works, there are many options, and you can do this! Best of luck! Suzanne

Posts.Content: May 27, 2011 07:06PM sdisilvestri wrote: So funny, my doctor used the exact same word with me yesterday, "salvagable".  At first I was put off by it, but then was just happy he was still willing to treat me aggressively.  I was really happy to read the technical definition, though.  By the way, I had eight liver tumors and they have all been completely gone for over a year, so there is tons of hope, even if they are cancer. Hang in there, waiting is the hardest part!
Posts.Title: So, looks like it happened.... CoolBreeze apple

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2010 06:31PM sdisilvestri wrote: For my 21st birthday I was expecting a ring from my then boyfriend (now husband of 15 years).  We had been dating for 3 years and I figured it was about time.  With lots of drama, he presented me with...a stick blender.  I couldn't hide the shock on my face.  We still laugh about it and he fully acknowledges he had no clue.  He has gotten much, much better, thank goodness (perhaps that's why we're still married?). For the record, after I stopped hating the stick blender for what it wasn't, I realized that it was a very useful kitchen item and to this day I use it to blend soup stovetop.  Beats transfering it to the blender! Suzanne

Posts.Title: Official,Joining Stage IV :( amlg1 lwd

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2011 08:08PM sdisilvestri wrote: Ann, I had stereotactic radiosurgery to get at a met on my spine a few months ago.  I was told the pain would abate immediately and, indeed, have read that this is nearly always the case with this procedure.  However, my pain level remains about the same. Nonetheless, my recent PET shows that previously intense metabolic activity is now gone from that particular met so I can't say I regret the procedure.  It (along with a rib that also received radiation, albeit the traditional kind) was my only active met and since both are now resolved and all is quiet, I am very pleased with the results. I am now considering that the pain was never related to the cancer (none of my other innumerable bone mets ever caused me any pain) and perhaps I have a slipped disc or something of the sort. PM me if you have any other questions. The procedure itself was painless and quick, but I was REALLY tired and weak for a few days following.  And now I have some strange numbness lateral to the area in my ribs but have no idea if that is related or not.

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2010 12:39AM sdisilvestri wrote: No surgery for me...both onc and surgeon agreed that it would not extend my life at all (and believe me, I did ask for a second opinion on that!).  I, too, have read pros and cons of stage IV surgery, but my docs are on the same page that it does not help to "close the barn door after the horse is already out", as my onc so eloquently put it. I have no psychological reason to remove my breast, so I am happy with their ruling. Suzanne
Posts.Title: How many of you did not have surgery? Suebus Chris93

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2011 12:28PM sdisilvestri wrote: I am on vacation right now with my husband and 7 children just north of San Francisco. This is the longest I have been away from UCLA since diagnosis nearly two years ago and it has been soooooo good for us all! We are staying with good friends, the older boys are doing football camp while I take the smaller ones to the beach or the park and actually listen to what they are saying to me for a change. I have unexplainably had very little appetite since March and lost about 15 pounds. Since I have been here, however, my appetite has come back completely and I have gained at least 5 of them back cooking and eating with my friend and getting treats with the kids. Makes me wonder if it isn't related to the day to day stress of dealing with this illness and nothing more. It is not healthy for us to think about cancer constantly, yet that is certainly what I do. This vacation has been the farthest I have been from cancer clinically, emotionally and physically since I got on this roller coaster. So, yes, ladies, go on vacation. It is a much needed break from it all! When I get home next week I have an excisional biopsy, a brain scan and my regular infusion to look forward to. But this week? I'm going to Alcatraz with my daughter!
Posts.Title: Anyone have a real or imaginary vacation planned in the future? cookie97 NewReality

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2011 02:40PM sdisilvestri wrote: I am.  Going well so far, few side effects from the drug. I have been on it for 16 months.  I had a complete response, with both the tumor in my breast and the dozen or more liver lesions disappearing completely.  The bones have been totally inactive as well until my most recent scan a few weeks ago showed three new/reactive lesions on rib and spine.  This bone activity did not kick me off the trial so I continue on and will until there is progression anywhere other than bones.  Feel free to ask me anything you are wondering about, either here or via PM. Suzanne
Posts.Title: TDM-1 MKOHIO sdisilvestri

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2011 08:01PM sdisilvestri wrote: I have to ramp up and down on the pain meds according to how my bone mets are doing.  One time I quit cold turkey and that was not fun.  The next time I took half as much each day until I was off and I had virtually no withdrawl effects.  But if she has been taking a lot (I was only taking a max of 3-4 Norco a day at the height) I would definitely agree that she should do this under a doctor's supervision.

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2010 12:59AM sdisilvestri wrote: I was anemic when I began treatment.  The lowest I got was 8.2, I think, and my onc said he would transfuse if I dropped below 8.0.  I had extensive bone and liver mets, and, while I started off mildly anemic, it definitely got worse with the first few treatments.  Then, as the cancer began to clear the situation corrected itself.  So, not sure if it was the cancer in the bones, on the liver, or the treatment that caused it, but it did take care of itself as the treatments began to do their job. Good luck!
Posts.Title: bone mets and anemia cmhartley meima-Bev

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2011 12:48AM sdisilvestri wrote: I am at UCLA and have been very pleased with my treatment for the most part.  Fantastic surgeon, amazing and compassionate oncologist, not my favorite radiation oncology experience but very effective.  What I love most is that everything happens in one place and I don't have to mess with taking my records all over and that all the docs talk to eachother.  I definitely recommend UCLA  Did very well on a study drug for a long time, which is why I picked a research hospital. Heard great things about City of Hope and Cedars both.  Don't think you can go wrong.
